text: The store is supported by that DC have reduced their backroom inventory by more than a third and cut hub stocks to half of what we see across the rest of the chain. Of course, we did all that with an entirely new facility and we are expanding that operation to support more stores in the Northeast, but we are also testing how to work to retrofit our existing network and by the fourth quarter, multiple DCs will begin the journey to evolve to this small.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: To do it we are scaling some of the most promising robotic solutions we have tested in the past year. That automation makes it possible for us to sort and move huge volumes of single units without putting an unsustainable burden on our DC teams or the stores.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: With less inventory in the back of the store, we can dedicate more room to digital fulfillment. This past holiday season we tested a new design at the backroom, complete with more pack stations and dedicated space to sort orders for delivery and capacity shot up. It was incredible as orders came pouring in on Cyber Monday, the teams were picking, packing and sorting boxes, just like a fulfillment center. And with enhanced layout and process, they did up to six times the volume of the year before.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Best of all, guest got their packages faster. Nearly every order that came into those stores that day was picked, packed and ready to ship in 24 hours. This year to keep up with digital demand that continues to far outpaced the industry, we are introducing this new backroom design to more than 150 stores and we are reengineering the operation in more than 1,000 others. With this additional capacity our stores plan to ship nearly double the number of packages for Cyber Monday 2018 compared to last year.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: That's good news, because as I said earlier, shipping more order from our stores reduces our costs, while allowing us to move faster and speed is the part our guest will notice. But the changes we've been making across our operation these past two years, the average delivery time for an order was nearing two days. But we weren't doing it consistently enough to make that promise to our guests, until now.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: We are announcing today that we are offering free two-day shipping on hundreds of thousands of items, no membership required. With more mature fulfillment capabilities we are updating our promise and resetting our guest expectations of what's possible. It's an offer that's compelling and competitive and it's just the start.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Speaking of being competitive, one of the biggest leaps we made this past year was our swift moving to same day delivery. With our acquisition of Shipt, Target gain the ability to deliver product to our guests in hours or even minutes. We knew Shipt was a fit for Target right from the start.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Here a start up delivery company that's gone from one market in Alabama to more than 70 markets in just three years. So the operation is strong and proven to scale. It's a company built on speed but focused on service, which means working the Shipt we could jump years ahead in our fulfillment plans, without sacrificing the guest's experience. Staying true to how we've grown for more than 50 years. Take a look.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Just eight weeks after our announcement we began offering millions of guests the ability to shop online for more than 50,000 items across groceries, essentials, electronics, baby and more, and have those products delivered that same day.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Already we brought Target same-day delivery to Shipt members across the Southeast and in the Twin Cities and we are rolling into new markets almost every week. By holiday we will be the first retailer to offer same-day delivery in nearly every major market.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: As you just heard, the beauty of Shipt is that it's not just a transaction. Our guests will get a personalized service and care that these shoppers offer unlike anyone else. While also accessing a wide assortment of products, priced right daily and delivered in hours. That whole package is something no one else is offering today.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: At the same time, guests still like to come into our stores and shop. But for guests in urban areas like Manhattan, they can only buy what they can carry home. Last year, our team saw a need and knew we could help.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Just weeks later they brought a service at our Tribeca location in New York City where guest shop the store and then play a fat -- flat fee, but the cost of a short cab ride, very cheap, very inexpensive to have that order delivered that same day.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Today we are offering delivery from four stores in New York and guests love it. It's quick and efficient and it's all possible, because the technology we acquired from Grand Junction last year. The platform assigns, every order to the most logical local carrier, which is what allows us to efficiently scale the service beyond a single store or market.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Starting this spring we will go even bigger in the city, offering the service in 25 more New York locations and reaching all five boroughs by Q4. And at the same time we roll it out in other markets like Boston, Chicago, San Francisco and DC.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Delivery goes a long way in making our guest lives easier, but just as meaningful as when a team member can put formula and diapers right in the back of a minivan, saving the guest from unloading the car seats to run inside.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Last summer we started testing Drive Up in the Twin Cities. It took order pick up to the parking lot where our stores teams will walk the order out to a guest car. We saw the demand for it right away and guest feedback was overwhelmingly positive. In fact, Drive Up's net promoter score is consistently over 80 and those you are familiar with that metric know that's incredibly high.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: This spring at the same time we take Shipt across the country we will roll up Drive Up putting the service in nearly 1,000 stores by the end of the year and every fulfillment option, shipping, delivering, walking orders to the car, the store is at the center. It also continues to be a destination for millions of guests every week, while fielding much of our digital growth at the same time. So we have to be sure they are equipped to do both.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Brian and I spent a lot of time visiting stores across the country. A little over year ago we toured a few markets together and it was clear, stores that we lean on so heavily needed some love, not only did the design need to refresh and by that I mean losing the neon and the vintage signs, but many of the layouts weren't set up to handle digital fulfillment.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: We walked stores where the team was holding order pick up packages in backroom meeting areas, because they didn't have space up front, or boxing orders in one of our backroom cranny that could fit a pack station. So our store design team developed a new prototype that would do it all.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: They re-imagine the entrances, sales floor and fixtures to make shopping our stores easier and more inspiring. At the same time they extended the order pick up counter, built a Drive Up lane and rearrange the backroom to handle a growing number of digital orders. In November, we open a new store in Houston with this latest generation of design. Check it out.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: We are incorporating elements of this latest design as we remodel more than 1,000 stores across the country over the next three years, including the 325 we will do in 2018. But it won't be the same in every store, we will adjust and evolve, applying what we learned and leaning into what works and we will continue to design experience that feels relevant for each location, from cinema lights on the former theater in Brooklyn, the big skylights at the store near Sunny UC Irvine.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: The fulfillment capabilities our stores gain are critical for our strategy, but so is the improved guest experience that comes from updating a store that hasn't been touched in years and the difference is real. After stores remodel, traffic grows and we see the 2% to 4% sales lift on average that we would expect it.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: In addition to the individual stores we are remodeling, we have made investments in key markets. Take the Dallas-Fort Worth area. Last year we remodeled 28 stores across the metro and guests noticed. The refresh design is inviting guests come back in and to shop, and the reviews have been overwhelmingly positive. We saw with Dallas and with LA 25 a few years ago that we can learn a lot from putting our latest thinking into one market. So this year we will go big in our hometown and remodel nearly 30 stores in the Twin Cities, on our way to putting the latest design into all area stores over the next few years.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Even as we re-imagine our existing stores, we are continuing to find opportunities to bring an elevated experience to new guests and we are doing that with our small format stores. The flexible design allows to open in areas where our traditional big-box footprints simply wouldn't fit, city centers, dense neighborhoods, even college campuses, they bring us into new markets like Vermont, which will officially put us in all 50 states and closer to new guests, like students at the University of Cincinnati and Penn State.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Part of joining a new community is being a good neighbor. So our teams go deep into those neighborhoods to really know those guests and tailor the experience to what they need. It's a capability we built and refined over time.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: You can see that most easily with our assortment. Of course, we have got portable electronics, and mac & cheese in our campus stores. But we also get specific to a neighborhood, even within the same city. Chicago is a great example. The assortment in our Lakeview Aspen store is focused on baby and kids products, because that's what those guessed buy most, while just seven blocks away Lakeview Belmont over indexes on top selling categories like home décor and liquor.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Last year we opened nearly 30 small format stores, doubling the number we'd opened up to that point. This year we will add another 30. In fact we are opening a few of them tomorrow in DC, Boston and Chicago, and we will do another 30 in 2019, putting us on paste to operate more than 130 small formats by the end of next year. So we can meet the needs of even more guests across the country.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Now all that said, it's the team inside those buildings that make us Target and our teams work hard to deliver for our guests and serve our communities every single day. So we are continuing to invest in them.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: You heard our announcement of increasing our minimum wage to $12 an hour this year on our way to $15 an hour by 2020 and while pay is important our investment goes deeper than that. We are also giving our team opportunities to develop and use new school -- skills that offer outstanding guest service, while also building the basket.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Gone are the days when the team member shows up on Monday to work on Apparel and Wednesday to work on electronics. Instead we are placing people based on their interests and their background and providing data and paid training to help them truly be specialists in their areas. In fact we have committed hundreds of thousands of payroll hours for training that helps them succeed in their jobs but also in their careers.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: At the same time we are giving them tools to better serve the in-store guests. Last year we launched an application on the team member device that allows them to order something for a guest if the item they want wasn't in their store. This holiday season it save the sale and extended the aisle for thousands of guests.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And soon our teams will use the same technology to save guests from standing in line. When the check lanes are full, our team can use the devices to give us more capacity at point-of-sale. They are able bring up a guest's full order on the spot, busting lines and saving time. It's just another way they are equipped to make a guest experience easier and more convenient.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: We have always said that the guest is at the center of everything we do. So it only makes sense that are 1,800 stores in neighborhoods across the country are at the center of how we do it. It's why you will see our progress continue to support our stores, whether it's modernizing the supply chain, standing up new small formats, building on digital capabilities, or most importantly, investing in our team, all of it is in service of delivering a retail experience guests can't find anywhere but Target. Thank you.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Wow, just like Brian said, what a difference a year makes. Coming out of this meeting a year ago we were really confident that we're on the right path, even so, we knew we would be a show me story for a while. We need to begin putting some points on the board to show that our strategy was working and now that started happening. But let me be clear, I know for some of you we still remain a show me story and we remain confident in our path. But I'd all -- but I think we all agree we are in a much different place today.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Last year was the beginning of a multiyear effort to position our business for long-term profitable growth. It was an investment year, as we ramped up our capital spending and devoted a portion of our operating income to reposition Target in this new era of retail.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Looking back, I'm happy to say that we made all of those investments and more, and with those investments our business performed far ahead of our expectations, both on the toplines and the bottomlines.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: In particular multiple data points either met or exceeded our expectations, including a 2% to 4% sales lift on average from our store remodels, compelling financial performance from our new small formats, including sales productivity, margins and ROIC, a strong guest response to our new brands, digital sales growth of more than 25% for the fourth year in a row, disciplined execution and a positive guest response to our new -- a test of our new fulfillment centers -- fulfillment options and following our investments in being priced right daily, our guest noticed with our sales at everyday low prices were up more than $4 billion compared to 2016. And finally, the most important metric, guest traffic, it accelerated as the year progressed.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Last year we said that 2018 would be a transition year and that view is still appropriate today. Our priorities remain the same, but you'll see a rapid acceleration in our pace. To support that acceleration we will grow our capital investment to well over $3 billion this year. To provide a differentiated shopping experience we will triple the size of our remodel program.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: We will open more than 30 small format stores and new neighborhoods. We will expand fulfillment options into new markets across the country, including Drive Up and the same day delivery enabled by Shipt acquisition.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: We will build capacity to ship more orders from our stores, increasing speed and reducing cost. We will continue investing in our supply chain to enhance the store replenishment and digital fulfillment. We will differentiate with more exclusive brands combined with our curated assortment of national brands. And we will continue to monitor and maintain the right balance of everyday prices and promotions by category. These are important investments to create the Target of tomorrow, which will position this company for growth in 2019 and beyond.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: In 2018 we expect that our EPS from our core business will stabilize. This reflects several profit headwinds, including accelerated depreciation resulting from our remodel program, continued cost pressure from the rapid rollout of our new fulfillment options, ongoing wage investments in the face of a tight labor market across the country and the impact of last year's price and value investments, which will annualize throughout 2018.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: However, unlike last year we will expect these pressures will be mostly offset by multiple tailwinds in our business, including the mix benefit of continued strength in our high margin categories, lower unit costs for digital fulfillment driven by our supply chain, modest expense leverage from a low single-digit increase in comparable sales, and of course, continued cost control across every aspect of our business.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: And finally, beyond operating income, we expect to benefit from the continued focus on disciplined capital deployment through lower interest expense and modest EPS leverage from share repurchase.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: This highlights one of the most important aspects of our business. It's ability to generate cash year after year. Look at 2017 even with an operating margin decline driven by our investments we generated almost $7 billion of cash from operations. That is $1.5 billion more than 2016, nearly a 30% increase, despite the massive changes happening in our industry. So even without Tax Reform, we would have entered 2018 in a really strong position.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Now let me pause for a moment and talk about Tax Reform. As a domestic retailer we have long had one of the highest effective tax rates around, well over 30% in recent years. So we are certainly encourage the Tax Reform has put our company, our industry on a more level playing field and made the United States more competitive globally.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: But the question we've heard a lot since Tax Reform was passed, what are you going to do with the benefits? And when you think about that question, it is important to realize we didn't wait for Tax Reform to make big investments in our business and our team, because we were confident they were the right long-term choices.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Think back to our second quarter conference call in August when we first announced we plan to invest more than $3 billion in our business in 2018 and then a month later when we took decisive action in support of our single most important differentiator, our team. We announced higher investments in hours training to better equip our team to provide an outstanding guest experience. And to support our team members, we announced we would raise Target's national minimum wage to $11 an hour as part of a plan to reach $15 by the end of 2020. And again today we have made another step forward with the announcement of our national starting wage is moving to $12.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Beyond investments in our team, we are accelerating our capital investments as well. Today we are raising our CapEx guidance to arrange around $3.5 billion dollars in 2018, reflecting the incremental investments in both our stores and our supply chain in support of the priorities I outlined earlier.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: So for us the question -- the answer to question, what are you going to do in light of Tax Reform is simple, we are investing in our business and our team to support Target's long-term sustainable growth, using the same approach we always have.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Now you've heard us say it so many times, we first look to invest in projects that promise to have -- to generate long-term value, then we want to support our dividend to extend the record -- our record of annual increases, and finally, we look to return any excess cash beyond those first two priorities within the limits of our middle A credit rating.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: So, with that, let's cover a few details underlying our financial expectations for 2018 and then we'll talk about the first quarter. Back in January, we outlined our expectations for a low single-digit increase in comparable sales this year and a full year adjusted EPS of $5.15 to $5.45, and today those expectations remain the same.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Among the drivers we expect our operating margin rate will be down about 20 basis points this year, reflecting the net impact of the headwinds and tailwinds I outlined earlier. Across the lines of the P&L we are expecting relatively small changes in gross margin and SG&A in 2018, which together should net to approximately zero.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: So in essence this year's expected decline in our operating margin rate will be driven entirely by $175 million increase in depreciation and amortization. One note, this is -- this expected increase is smaller than I outlined in our last conference call. Since then we have continued to refine our outlook and expect less year-over-year D&A pressure in the year as it goes on specifically in the third and fourth quarters.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Beyond operating metrics, we expect our interest expense to decrease about $60 million this year, reflecting last year's debt retirement and refinancing activities conducted by our treasury team. And finally, we expect our consolidated tax rate to be in the low to mid-20% range, lower than in recent -- recent history in light of Tax Reform.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Now I'll turn briefly to our expectations for the first quarter. On the topline, we are planning for a low single-digit increase in our first quarter comparable sales. We are expecting a moderate increase in our first quarter gross margin rate, which will be more than offset by an increase in our SG&A expense rate and we are expecting an increase in our first quarter D&A expense of about $80 million consistent with the outlook I provided on our last conference call.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Altogether, this adds up to a decline in operating margin rate of 60 basis points to 80 basis points in the first quarter, combined with a reduction in our interest expense of about $20 million and the benefit of the lower tax rate we are expecting first quarter adjusted EPS to be $1.25 to $1.45.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: One final note on our guidance. As you began seeing in our results last year, our new stores are starting to have a meaningful impact on our total sales growth. As a result, in 2018 for both the first quarter and the full year we expect that our new stores will add approximately 50 basis points to our total sales growth.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: So now I want to step back and talk a minute about how our financial model is changing. While we are not going to provide long-term guidance today, we can offer a strategic view. With the changes we're making to our business model, we expect our financial model to evolve as well. Like the past we will continue to focus on growing traffic sales and profits enabled by our strategic investments we've highlighted today, and our stores will be right at the center of that growth, providing an outstanding shopping experience along with fast and efficient digital fulfillment in support of a rapidly growing suite of convenient options.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: By placing our stores at the center, we expect our business will generate somewhat higher asset turns and somewhat lower operating margins than we've seen historically. This evolution will support continued outstanding after-tax returns on invested capital, something that's been a strength of this company for a very long time.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: In fact, if you think back in our history, this isn't the first time our business model and financial model have changed in service of an evolving consumer. Remember our company began over 100 years ago as a traditional department store. It had a business model that generated higher margin rates and lower asset turns compared with Target stores, yet even as we completely transformed our business model from department stores to Target stores, our company has generated strong returns on capital for decades.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Even in 2018 an investment year, we earned a very healthy 14% after-tax ROIC and that's after we exclude the one-time benefits from Tax Reform. This is performance that many in our industry would love. And in 2018 we expect ROIC to move beyond 14% even in the face of increase in capital spending.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: As we look past 2018, we don't believe that margin rates are going to unsustainably low levels and we can clearly see a path to evolve our financial model and reward investors by delivering growth and attractive returns consistent with the long-term record of this great company. We know we serve as stewards of a company that will have a very long history and I can assure you that this leadership team is all in, in sustaining that great legacy we've inherited.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: So now I want to end my remarks where Brian began with a shout out to our team. As soon as I came to Target I quickly realized how special this team really is. I see it every day that I'm on our stores, walking the sales floor or when I'm visiting our distribution centers are every day in our headquarters.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: No matter where they are or what they do, when you spend time with our team, you feel first-hand the pride they have in our company, our brand and the role Target serves in every community we are in.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: They share a common purpose to bring joy to our guest lives and they project an infectious sense of optimism. They see clearly that Target will succeed if we focus on the long-term and make the right choices, for our business, for our team, for our guests and our shareholders.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: So while there's no question that times were tough a year ago, our teams passion and energy never faded. Our team embraced the challenge to move faster and think bigger, and begin moving Target from a show me story to a long-term success story again. So I want to say thank you to the entire Target team for everything you do. It's a privilege to work with you as we write this new chapter in our history.

label: Remarks
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: So now I am going to turn it back over to Brian for a brief wrap up and then we'll move to questions. Thank you.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So I love the way Cathy just brought it all together. We have an incredibly talented team at Target and they truly delivered in 2017. I couldn't be more proud of their ambition, their passion for the brand and the way they always do the right thing for our guests.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: When you think about 2017, you heard it from Cathy and John, it was in every sense an investment year. We made big bets on new brands, new experiences and capabilities. We leaned into new partnerships and empowered our people. 2017 was a year of progress.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: As we look to the year ahead, 2018 is all about scale and acceleration. So we are tripling the remodel program. We will add another 30 small formats. We will introduce many new brands. We are rolling out new service models and game changing fulfillment capabilities, and making even deeper investments in our team. And I'm really confident about what's next.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: I'll be the first to say, we still have a lot of work to do. The competition is fierce. The pace of change is unrelenting and our guest deserves the very best. But I couldn't be more bullish about Targets prospects.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: The strategy we are pursuing is working. Our guests are responding and now our team is more than ready to pick up the pace, and move faster than we ever have before, with one goal in mind to make Target America's easiest place to shop.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: All right. So I am going to ask John and Cathy to join us on stage. We are going to answer some of your questions. In addition to questions in the room here today, we also have questions coming from our webcast. We are going to try to make sure we incorporate those into the approximate 30 minutes we have for Q&A today. So we've got mic runners. They will have bulls-eyes in their hand, I would ask as you ask your question if you can just pause, identify yourself, we can see many of you, but not very well. So why don't we start with sitting in right up front. I can see up to about the second, so it was an advantage.

label: Question
speaker: Unidentified Analyst
text: Thanks. Good morning. Thanks, Brian.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Good morning.

label: Question
speaker: Unidentified Analyst
text: I want to focus on two items that I have been pressuring margins, first, investments and capabilities, investments being the catchall including wage? And then the second pressure point is the shift to lower margin channel and can ask you to comment on each, where you are in terms of your spend, the SG&A guide sort of implies that we've reached some peak level and we are going to taper off and then second with regard to the mix shift online, where are you in that journey. You said the customer is agnostic, are you financially agnostic?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah. So let me start and I'll turn it over to Cathy and John. I think as we outlined today. We have made significant investments in last year, in our team, in new capabilities and new brands. You are going to see that stabilize as we go into 2018 and as Cathy mentioned in our outlook, we expect to see gross margin rates stabilize, if not slightly improve in 2018, offset by some of the investments we will make in SG&A.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So I think we have reached the point of general stability in our model. We are going to continue to invest. It's a period of now acceleration. But we have spent a lot of time over the last three years, testing and validating our investments, making sure the right thing for our guests, the right thing for our shareholders, they are going to be sustainable and they are also going to provide the right return on invested capital and I think you saw that today in our outlook.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So, again, we've got a lot of work to do in 2018. It is a year of acceleration. But we are accelerating based on the validation that we saw in '18 and the confidence that we are going to continue to drive great returns.

label: Answer
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: The only thing I would add, I mean is, kind of longer-term that perspective of as our business model is evolving, I am using the stores at the center of that strategy, we do expect that you'll see continued really terrific ROIC or after-tax ROIC. And so kind of probably lower operating margins that we've seen historically not inconsistent with where we are today, but really strong continued asset efficiency, which will drive the ROIC, so growth in ROIC.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And your question about digital and the mix between the two channels, as I said several times today, we really want to make Target America's easiest place to shop, allow our guests to interface with great stores and even better store experiences as we remodel, give them a number of options for fulfillment, whether it's order online and pick up in our store, now Drive Up to our lot and pop that trunk and we will put it right in there, use Shipt to provide same-day delivering in hours if not minutes and convenient service right to their home. So we have to be agnostic, let the guest decide.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: But one of the great highlights from our fourth quarter was the fact that we saw really strong traffic and growth both in our stores and our digital channel, and we expect as we go into 2018 to continue to drive positive growth into our stores to drive positive comps in stores that's critically important and to continue to be a leader in digital growth. I think the investments we're making in Shipt, in Drive Up and other services positions Target uniquely as we move into this next era of retailing. Right over here.

label: Question
speaker: Wayne Hood
title: BMO Capital Markets
text: Just to follow up on his question, looking at the spin rate in remodels maybe peaking by 2020 the wage investments, it's actually peaking then as well. Why wouldn't you expect operating margins to lift in 2020 given the run-off in D&A and the spent is actually over? And then I have a question about, John, if you talk a little bit about the execution -- a lot of I heard -- what we have seen so far today is absence some of the improved processes, but it didn't really address maybe the headwind in the store, it's the modular issue that the systems will get the right quantities, but the challenge is the modular are not really set in a way that allows that the flow very as nice as you would like see. So how do you address that the modular side is the store format begins to change over time?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: John, let me start with the first part of the question. And Wayne you are absolutely right. As we get into the out years, we are going to see our remodel schedule begin to normalized, right now we are in a catch-up state and as we accelerate over the next three years, obviously, we will touch the vast majority of our stores. So in the out years we do expect that to normalize. But we have a lot of work to do in these next few years. It's all about making sure we execute our plan and touch and enhance the experience in as many stores as possible before we returned to a normal remodel schedule.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: I'm sorry, Wayne, I didn't fully understand your second part of your question.

label: Question
speaker: Wayne Hood
title: BMO Capital Markets
text: I probably didn't ask it right, but I will ask it again.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah.

label: Question
speaker: Wayne Hood
title: BMO Capital Markets
text: So the challenge to me has always been on store replenishment side was the modulars really are not of the size that allows you to get a full case back on to the modular…

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah.

label: Question
speaker: Wayne Hood
title: BMO Capital Markets
text: …and you can do all the backroom maneuvering that you want to do that gives you so far, but those modulars over time since we have to change to allow for better quantities, what you want to and then you take into account how the store is changing and what modulars may or may not present there in five years to 10 years now you maybe look at another remodel around based on the modular side?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah. I think this goes back to why we talk about flexibility in the supply chain to address that. I think when you look we are at today and you are right, it will evolve over the next 10 years, I -- who knows what will have in store then, maybe Mark does, but that will come later, 70% of that stuff doesn't sell more than one per store per week, so I don't need to flow case packs into that store for those items, you think about bike helmets, the likelihood of us selling more than one bike helmet in a week, this time a year in Minneapolis is very low.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: We may sell one and probabilistically we will sell one sometime this month, but we won't sell more than that and so that's why we go back to flexibility. There's things that are going to have to go in there in a very high speed, high-capacity, to your point we need to make sure a case pack fits on the floor or case pack in half or three case packs in the case of Tide or eight case packs or 20 case packs, because we will move that in pallet loads.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: But for the majority of what we sell much lower volumes that needs to come in in single units and so it's really about having that flexibility upstream to meet the demands of whatever it is we are doing in store and that's why we are headed down the path we are.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And to go on the side of the room. Oliver?

label: Question
speaker: Matthew Fassler
title: Goldman Sachs
text: I am sorry, it's actually, hi, it's Matt Fassler from Goldman Sachs.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Hi, Matt. You guys look exactly alike.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: From here.

label: Question
speaker: Matthew Fassler
title: Goldman Sachs
text: Thanks a lot for your remarks today so far. I have got a question -- I've got a question about the level and cadence of expense growth as you move through the year, the guidance that you gave for Q1 and then for the year as a whole would imply that the expense profile improves as we move through the year. As the wage growth piece seems like it will be persistent, are there expenses that fade as you go through the year, are there cost out opportunities that build or is there topline acceleration implied in the guidance? Thanks so much.

label: Answer
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Yeah. It's a little bit of, I talked about all of the tailwinds and it is a little bit of all of those things. So we will see some leverage because of the continued comp sales increase. We will see some continued cost control as we move throughout the year that we have plan. So it's kind of the combination of the four different tailwinds and none of the headwinds.

label: Question
speaker: Matthew Fassler
title: Goldman Sachs
text: And if I could just ask a quick follow-up, you also shared lots of topline drivers, you talked about remodels, the new brand Shipt, free two-day shipping for a large array of goods. Can you talk about how those layer into the revenue forecast over the course of the year?

label: Answer
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Well, we gave first quarter guidance, I can start, John, I guess, we gave first quarter guidance, obviously, low single-digit and we gave full year guidance low single-digit, and those all contemplate, obviously, our continued brand rollouts, as well as all of our fulfillment expansion. So those are all included in that low single, just so happen is Q1 and full-year.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah. And much of the digital, absent the two-day which is effective today.

label: Answer
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Yeah.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: The Shipt and Drive Up, those the two big ones that will expand nationally our goal. You will see a pretty linear ramp up through the end of Q3 and our goal is to have all of that done ready for Q4 to redone and that will all ramp up as we go along throughout the year.

label: Question
speaker: Matthew Fassler
title: Goldman Sachs
text: Thank you so much.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: We'll go back upfront.

label: Question
speaker: John Zolidis
title: Buckingham Research
text: Brian we got one from the webcast participants, we got somebody that said they applaud us for the CapEx that we have projects that are high returning, wondered after this wave of remodels is over, the 1000 over the next three years, what a more normalized level of CapEx might look like in the longer term?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: I think most of you know we are not going to provide long-term guidance. We are not going to provide long-term CapEx guidance. But we are going to continue to look at different projects that add value and provide great returns for our shareholders. We will be looking in the future to think about how we continue to provide a great physical and digital experience for our guests and make the right investments that continue to add value for our shareholders. So we don't have a long-term guidance that we are going to provide today for CapEx John but we are going to continue to take the same disciplined and surgical approach to CapEx that you have seen over the last few years.

label: Question
speaker: John Zolidis
title: Buckingham Research
text: Right.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Why don't we go upfront, I will give all the chance since I jump over on the floor.

label: Question
speaker: Oliver Chen
title: Cowen & Co.
text: Thank you. Good morning and thanks for the presentation.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Good morning.

label: Question
speaker: Oliver Chen
title: Cowen & Co.
text: The digitization of the supply chain is likely key to unlocking the asset turns. What do you think about that with respect to algorithms, as well as your relationships with vendors and as you think about robots and making sure that's on track?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: John?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah. So all things we are working on, Oliver, you heard me talk about, we spent the last 12 months testing automation and I think five different facilities, various different forms of automation, bringing them together in different combinations in the Perth Amboy facility on the Northeast, we are starting implementation of 1 Vio of that. We are implementing something different here in DC located in Fridley, so that's a piece of it. We have a large team working on supply chain analytics, primarily located, but not exclusively located out in the Bay area, working with Mike's team to provide the technology and the analytics in combination, and again if you look at Perth Amboy, Mike's team built an entirely new warehouse management system and then there is the analytics attached to it to move how much inventory. So we are moving down the path on all of those together. It is going to take all of those to deliver what we want from a supply chain perspective.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And Oliver, we try to showcase obviously a lot of the initiatives today, give you a chance to interact with the team, see the work that we are doing today. What underpin so much of that is the work we're doing from a data and analytical standpoint. So our team in Sunnyvale that's supporting Mark and his team to make better assortment choices, better pricing and promotional choices. Mike's team of engineers that's driving so much of the work we are doing as we reinvent how we run our stores, how we fuel our supply chain.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So the commitment and the investments we are making in our team go well beyond what you've seen today and a lot of it is to make sure we have cutting-edge data analytics. We have got great engineer and computer scientists that are helping Mike and Mark and Rick make better decisions from a merchandising standpoint, a digital standpoint and a marketing standpoint, and that's certainly to fuel our business as we go forward for years to come.

label: Question
speaker: Oliver Chen
title: Cowen & Co.
text: Last question Is about value, what are your thoughts about value in terms of making sure you communicate a clear value and as we model comp store sales, should we continue to see your check size versus traffic, how do you think that will evolve and stocking versus fill up?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah. I think one of the great highlight this year that we really didn't cover is the work that was done between Mark's merchandising team and Rick Gomez's marketing team. To make sure that as we made these investments to be price right daily. We communicated that to our guests. Both in-store from a personalize standpoint and throughout the year in our marketing and advertising campaign, and I think it was the combination of all that work that yielded the benefits that Cathy talked about today, that significant makes the $4 billion of sales from promo to every day.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So as we go forward we will continue to remind our guests that we offer great value that we are price right daily on thousands of items across the store and I think one of the great turning points for our business this year was the balance that we brought back to advertising Target style, but also letting our guests know every single week that we were price right daily and there was great value within the store. And I think that's driving traffic. I think that played a significant part in the traffic increases we saw in the fourth quarter. That's driving basket.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And beyond some of the numbers that we've shared it driving an acceleration in units in those important personal and essential categories. So that commitment to value and being price right daily, we think is critically important to driving traffic, to leveraging our multi-category portfolio, and making sure people are shopping is not only for the great style brands that our teams are bringing to market, but those household essentials that bring cars in our parking lot and click store site every single week. So that commitment to value is something that you'll see throughout '18 and for years to come. Why don't we go to the back of the room and I will let you pick a hand because unfortunately from here we can't see. So if you can identify yourself we would really appreciate it.

label: Question
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Hi. It's Bob Drbul from Guggenheim Securities.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Hi, Bob.

label: Question
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Brian and the two question I have, I guess, the first one is, as you look at the full year expectation for gross margin coming off of this holiday season. Can you just reiterate what you see from a gross margin and competitive perspective that gives you the confidence a flattish or up slightly gross margin?

label: Question
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And the second question is, I think, on the free two-day shipping program, will that be fulfilled out of the stores or is that going to be fulfillment center type, can you just elaborate on that expectation going forward?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So when I start from a margin standpoint and as we've talked about throughout the last few quarters. Our team has made significant progress as we have shifted our business from promo to every-day, the byproduct of that commitment to be price right daily. That's going to continue as we go forward.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: As you've seen over the last couple of days we will continue to introduce great new owned brands in those signature categories that as we all know our higher margin and provide a great return both in-store but also to our digital business. So we will continue to see the benefits of the analytics, the science that we are placing behind, our pricing and promo strategy, the shift from promotional sales to more regular priced business, the benefits as we bring new excitement into our stores with great innovation. That's going to continue to stabilize and improve our margins over time and it's a great point of differentiation.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So whether it's Opal House or Umbro or some of the things you saw this morning, many of the things that we will talk about over the balance of the year those higher margin home and apparel items, those great owned brands that you can only find at Target benefit not only our store margins but also our digital margins and we will continue to drive efficiency over time. John, you want to talk about fulfillment?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah. I think you will see -- next year this meeting you will see that our penetration of units delivered from stores will grow relative to 2017 and relative to two-day, absolutely, we would expect the majority of that to be delivered from store. We know that's the fastest place that can be delivered from.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: John, can we go to the webcast.

label: Answer
speaker: John R. Hulbert
title: Vice President-Investor Relations
text: Yeah. Thanks, Brian. We've got a variety of questions about Shipt, so I'll just give you all of them. One being are we getting new guests coming in because of Shipt yet. One the decision are to maintain the marketplace in other words share the marketplace with other retailers on the Shipt platform. And then, finally, the decision of why to require them versus to just become a partner on their platform?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: John, do you want to lead this one off?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Sure. I think, maybe I'll start with just, what are we trying to do with Shipt and then hopefully address some of those questions. We have three priorities for Shipt that we have been focused on since we close the acquisition. One is, scale Target nationally on the Shipt app and Shipt.com and we are well down that path. We are in 455 stores. We are adding markets every single week.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: The second was bring Shipt to Target.com, Mike and his team are working hard on that to provide that option for guests who come to us directly through Target.com we will provide same-day delivery service for our entire assortment.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And then third was expand the marketplace and I guess to get out a little bit of this. We think the value here is about bringing all those retailers together. That's the value of the membership. We know consumers have different reasons they go to different retailers, often they come to Target. We really like that. Sometimes they go other places. But bringing all of those retailers together on one marketplace is incredibly powerful to bring consumers into the Shipt app and so we had great conversations with other retailers. We already have great partners and HEB and Publix and Meyer, Cosco, all on the app and we will continue to grow that. So we are very interested in continuing to grow the marketplace.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And to the other question, Cathy, John and I all spent quite a bit of time looking at other same-day delivery options and we invested a lot of time getting to know the Shipt organization. We were attracted to Shipt and decided to take an ownership position because of that personal connection we saw with their member.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And as we spent time and went to Birmingham, work with some of their shoppers, saw the caliber of people that were shopping for Shipt, these moms were shopping for moms, the approach they took to really building a relationship, we felt it was so important to own that last mile touch and that human interaction that we think really differentiates Target from anyone else in that space. So we certainly had options to partner with other last mile delivery companies.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: But we thought Shipt had a very different approach. It wasn't just the transaction. It was building a relationship and we thought owning that human touch was very consistent with what we think is our greatest asset and that's our people that make such a difference as we talked to guests and they describe why they shop at Target, as I said early today, most of the answer is pretty simple, is because of our team. Okay.

label: Question
speaker: Peter Benedict
title: Robert W. Baird
text: Thanks. Peter Benedict at Baird. Two questions, first, the cost to upgrade these fulfillment centers modernization, John, you talked about, can you give a sense of maybe how much that is going to contribute to the capital spend over the next few years, what's the cadence, how many do you need to do and when do we get to the end point there?

label: Question
speaker: Peter Benedict
title: Robert W. Baird
text: And the second point question would be on inventory growth. How should we think about that as you kind of clean up the backrooms, you put the fall product over the supply chain, how should we think about into our growth maybe versus sales something?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah. I think first on the capital -- Cathy has provided the capital guidance, it's all within our capital guidance, everything we have talked about we have planned for, if that changes, I am sure, Cathy will come back and let you know that changes.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And I think pace we will know more about that actually near the end of this year than I do right now. We are very focused on getting the Perth Amboy facility up and operating and -- because that's kind of the end state. This is what great will look like.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Simultaneous with that, like I said, we are testing how we can start to evolve the broader network into that step by step by step and what we are doing this year would be the first step and we hope to have a decision about perhaps getting to eight of those realistically probably very early next year and then expand from there.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Meanwhile while we are doing that, go back into the local distribution center and say, okay, what's the next step we would bring to that in order to move it down the path. So that's kind of the sequence we are thinking about year-over-year. This won't happen over the next 18 months, because it can't. This is a conversation we have internally a lot.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: If we could like shutdown for nine months and not a deliver any product to stores we can get this done very quickly, but we don't have that ability. We need to keep producing product for the store. We are shipping product to the store, so it will be a gradual evolution over time, the investments will follow that gradual evolution.

label: Answer
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Can I answer the inventory question real quick for you? A longer term as we talked many times, Peter. We do see that inventory loads as we move product exactly where we need it, when we need it, we will continue to come down. Obviously, we want to make sure we have a great guest experience and we are in stock and so we are going to balance that as we are evolving the supply chain so through this transition and then obviously to support all of the wonderful new brands and products we are bringing in.

label: Question
speaker: Peter Benedict
title: Robert W. Baird
text: Got it.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So just to build on that, it is going to take time and as you've seen over the last couple years with the approach we have taken to a number of initiatives, we are going to test, learn, iterate and then move forward, and this is same model we took to own brands, starting with Cat & Jack, learning from that success and now we're building out the portfolio.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: The same approach we took to remodels. We started with 25 stores in LA. We continue to learn and listen and iterate and once we saw the right response from the guests and the right return on invested capital we move more quickly.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: We are doing the same thing from a DC standpoint. We are constantly learning and updating our approach and we think we've got a model that we can expand but we are going to do that very, very carefully and make sure that we have a system that can be scaled.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And when we get there to Wayne's question, we will see better units of measure flow into the stores, which will naturally improve inventory levels and working capital. But this is one that's going to take time. To John's point we are not shutting down our system for nine months. It's going to be a multiyear journey, but we are going to make sure that we do it right and we get the right returns and continue to provide the right experience for our guests. We have got a question upfront here.

label: Question
speaker: Gregory Melich
title: MoffettNathanson
text: Hi. It's Greg Melich with MoffettNathanson.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Hi, Greg.

label: Question
speaker: Gregory Melich
title: MoffettNathanson
text: So I had a follow up for Cathy and Brian another question. Cathy the $3.5 billion CapEx, that is I think about $500 million and what we are thinking before. Should we think about that, I know you are not giving long-term guidance, but does that more of a pull-forward of things that you had or more given what you see just this more stuff you want to lean into this year? And then, Brian, I had a follow-up?

label: Answer
speaker: Catherine R. Smith
title: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
text: Yeah. So consistent with our strategy, Brian, had laid out, we intend to remodel, we are seeing a great returns, 2% to 4% lift. We make sure we have great returns on invested capital with those and as we've seen the remodels perform we are going to continue to get towards that 1000 stores that Brian talked about, but and by the time we get there is much of our fleet will be much younger in age, obviously, some of the heavier needs are earlier on, which is why the capital is little higher. But I would expect we've done the $2.5 billion, $3.5 billion this year, obviously, we're not slowing down, we are seeing great returning and we are seeing a great response from our guests. So we are not giving long-term guidance, but you can expect that we will continue down those stores.

label: Question
speaker: Gregory Melich
title: MoffettNathanson
text: Okay. And then, Brian, you talk a lot about acceleration, right. What happened last year it's now time to really accelerate it? Could you talk a little bit more about the brand acceleration? I mean, it seems like with 12 brands and 12 months and is that a new run rate, I mean, can the organization really be expected to come up with that many new great brands and ideas every year or is there certain amount that you -- or could have become 18 in a year or is there certain amount of product that you sort of limited on that ultimately where we only want to change over a quarter of the SKUs or something like that?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So, Greg, I wouldn't expect that to be the long-term run rate. But certainly as the Mark and his team had look at the portfolio, we've seen opportunities through replacing the existing brands that's been our portfolio, fill new white spaces and over the balance of 2018 we will continue to bring newness and innovation own brands and then we will continue to listen to the guests, understand category trends and bring great newness and innovation, whether it's with a new own brand or some of the great partnerships we will continue to bring forward on a limited time basis like we announced earlier today.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So I wouldn't expect it to be the run rate right for Mark and his team, but we see significant opportunities to continue to strengthen our owned brand portfolio in 2018 and we will look for further opportunities in the years to come. Let's go to all the way at the back of the room.

label: Question
speaker: Bill Dreher
title: Deutsche Bank
text: Yeah. Thank you. Bill Dreher here from Susquehanna Financial Group. I have a regarding the renovations and remodels, how do you prioritize the renovations and remodels, are you working with the stores of the greatest opportunity, the older stores or how do you work on that? And then how do you -- how much of the new store remodel program can be brought in, not 100% of all the new module to be brought in, should we be expecting a similar 78% of modulars brought in and how does that rollout?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: John, do you want to talk about the remodel strategy?

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Yeah. So it's a little bit of everything you said actually when we are choosing the stores, we have model that helps us generate age, condition, when is the last time, part of that comes into it is how hard is this store shop, how high volume is it, what is the average basket, so do they get shopped really hard day in and day out.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And to your point, where can we have the biggest impact, where can we go and say, look these 10 stores or dozen stores we know that they are in need of it and we will have a big impact. So we go through a process. The team recommends those.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: They have conversations with the senior store leaders as well to get their local viewpoint about what's going on in that marketplace, as somebody opened up six grocery stores around us or whatever it is, and say, hey, this is one where we could really use the help competitively. So there's multiple pieces we come together with the team distills that down and then we come to a consensus about this is the list we are going to go after for this year.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: As you can imagine when you're do on the 100, that's a lot more difficult when you're doing -- then when you're doing 325, the list gets a lot more easy and a lot less contentious. So it's a great process. The team is already working on 2019 and actually thinking about 2020 us so that all happens much further in advance.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: To your question about what gets put into the remodel? Our goal is always to put in as many elements as we can in any individual store. The calibration though is we want to make sure that store can afford to have that much investment. And so lower volume stores get less and the great thing is and I've seen this happen multiple times when we say, hey, here is we are going to draw the line on lower volume, Brian, challenges the team, go figure out a way to get these two more elements into that store. They go back. They value engineered. They find ways to do it more efficiently. Certainly as we do more scale that brings efficiency to it and so we found ways to move some of the elements we really like even into those low volume remodels.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So I have got a note say it's time to wrap up this session. But before we close out, I do want to thank you for joining us in Minneapolis this week. We spent a lot of time debating where to hold this meeting and really thought based on stage of our journey it was the right time to have you here, so you could see our new renovated downtown store, spend quality time with our leadership team.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: This morning we wanted to give you a sense for all of these initiatives we are working on and how there are going to help us create the target of the future, give you a glimpse into some of the things we are doing from a technology standpoint, that's going to make it easier for our guests to shop at Target and easy for our team to support that guest. And I hope today we are able to give you a sense for our excitement for 2018.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: 2017 was a year of significant progress for this team. 2018 is all about acceleration. Taking all the learning that we've gathered over the last couple of years and really stepping on the accelerator and I think we're on our way to creating long-term value for our shareholders, but most importantly, continuing to differentiate our brand and ensuring Target is one of the long-term retail winners as we move forward.

label: Answer
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: So, thanks again for joining us, travel safely and we look forward to seeing you again later in the year. So thank you.

label: Operator
speaker: Operator
text: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Target Corporation Third Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. During the presentation, all participants will be in a listen-only mode. Afterward, we will invite you to participate in a question-and-answer session.

label: Operator
speaker: Operator
text: At the close of prepared remarks, we will open the queue for the Q&A session. [Call instructions delivered by operator]. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded Wednesday, November 17th, 2021. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. John Hulbert, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

label: Remarks
speaker: John R. Hulbert
title: Vice President-Investor Relations
text: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our third quarter 2021 earnings conference call. On the line with me today are Brian Cornell, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Christina Hennington, Chief Growth Officer; John Mulligan, Chief Operating Officer; and Michael Fiddelke, Chief Financial Officer.

label: Remarks
speaker: John R. Hulbert
title: Vice President-Investor Relations
text: In a few moments, Brian, Christina, John, and Michael will provide their perspective on our third quarter performance and our outlook and priorities for the fourth quarter and beyond. Following the remarks, we'll open the phone lines for a question-and-answer session. This morning, we are joined on this conference call by investors and others who are listening to our comments via webcast.

label: Remarks
speaker: John R. Hulbert
title: Vice President-Investor Relations
text: Following the call, Michael and I will be available to answer your follow-up questions. And finally, as a reminder, any forward-looking statements that we make this morning are subject to risks and uncertainties, the most important of which are described in our most recently filed 10-K.

label: Remarks
speaker: John R. Hulbert
title: Vice President-Investor Relations
text: Also in these remarks, we refer to non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted earnings per share, reconciliations of all non-GAAP numbers to the most directly comparable GAAP number are included in this morning's press release, which is posted on our Investor Relations website. With that, I will turn it over to Brian for his thoughts on the quarter and his perspective on our outlook. Brian?

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter results are consistent with what our team has been delivering quarter-after-quarter for years now. And they continue to demonstrate the extraordinary level of engagement we're seeing from our guests, both with our brand and with our team.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: In the third quarter, comparable sales expanded 12.7% on top of a nearly 21% increase 1 year ago. Consistent with recent quarters, traffic was the primary driver of this year's growth, as our guest increasingly turned to Target to serve their wants and needs. Across our sales channels, store sales were the primary growth driver this quarter, while same-day services propelled our digital growth.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Since the third quarter of 2019, prior to the pandemic, Q3 store sales have expanded by $3.8 billion, while digital sales have increased another $3.1 billion. This provides a vivid demonstration of the flexibility of our operating model to serve our guests no matter how they choose to shop.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: All of these results reflect a level of guest engagement far beyond what many would have imagined a few years ago when we started making huge investments throughout our business, in our stores, new brands, same-day services, supply chain, and importantly, our team. Back then, Target was already known for our world class team, a differentiated shopping experience, unique assortment, and an iconic brand.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: But we knew there was much more to do. We saw a clear opportunity to build on that solid foundation, finding new ways to enhance our capabilities while strengthening the bond with both our team and our guests. And today, those bonds have never been stronger. As I mentioned, within our digital capabilities, more and more of our guests are trying and embracing our industry-leading same-day services.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Third quarter sales through these services have expanded by nearly 400% or $2 billion over the last 2 years. Through the first 3 quarters of the year, sales through these services have grown by more than $6 billion since 2019, a number larger than the total sales of many prominent retailers.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: Beyond fulfillment capabilities our balanced, multi-category assortment is another key driver of flexibility and resiliency within our business model. The breadth of our assortment, both within and across our core categories, allows our team to quickly and seamlessly serve our guests, even when their wants and needs are changing rapidly. In the third quarter, we saw a consistent, strong growth across our entire merchandising portfolio.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: More specifically, all five of our core merchandise categories saw double-digit growth in the quarter, ranging from the low double-digits to the mid-teens, resulting in strong market share gains on top of unprecedented share growth in 2020. And we're not slowing down in our efforts to serve our guests. We continue to invest key partnerships that enhance our assortment and experience, including the opening of more than 100 Ulta Beauty shop-in-shops.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And our recent announcement that we're doubling the number of enhanced Apple experiences in electronics. Christina will provide more details in a few minutes. In our conference call 3 months ago, we outlined multiple actions we're taking to support our inventory and in-stocks, given the supply chain challenges that have emerged throughout the pandemic.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: As you know, those pressures only intensified in the third quarter, and our team has done an outstanding job in the face of these challenges, identifying bottlenecks and finding solutions to keep inventory flowing throughout our network. All those efforts drove some incremental costs in the quarter, we view them as a continuation of the many productive, long-term investments, we're making in our business in support of the trust we have built with our guests.

label: Remarks
speaker: Brian C. Cornell
title: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
text: And obviously, our guest responded to these efforts with strong Third-Quarter traffic, which we expect will continue in Q4 and beyond.
